column2: preparing for a round of major summits with Donald Trump
column3: are wary.  I spent much of the past week speaking with officials and cabinet ministers in Europe. All they wanted to talk about was Trump.¬† Here
column5: are the most frequent remarks I heard from them
column6: and from others in my travels
column7: in rough order of frequency: 1. Trump is unstable
column8: and we‚Äôre not going to count on anything he says or commits to.  2. Trump doesn‚Äôt support NATO or European integration.  3. Trump is actively encouraging racist nationalists in our country.  4. Trump is allied with Putin to bring Europe down.  5. There‚Äôs no doubt Trump worked with Putin to win the U.S. presidential election. 6. If Trump‚Äôs polls drop too low
column9: he‚Äôll start a war in order to get Americans to rally around him. (Opinions varied on whether Trump‚Äôs war would be with North Korea
column14: or Afghanistan.) 7. How did you Americans come to elect this ego-maniac? (Others called him an infant
column20: Hitler). 9. We remember fascism. We never thought it would happen in America.  10. The world depends on American leadership. We‚Äôre very worried. My overall impression: Anti-Trump sentiment is even stronger in Europe than it is in the U.S. If Trump expects his European trip to give him a reprieve from his troubles at home

column1: alohaspaceman 160952192001 "2017-05-22 16:50:04 GMT" https://alohaspaceman.tumblr.com/post/160952192001/how-alex-oloughlin-found-his-aloha-spirit "  It was early 2010 and the Australian actor had just been offered the lead role on the reboot of the classic crime drama Hawaii Five-0
column2: stepping into the shoes of the legendary Jack Lord to play the 50th state‚Äôs taciturn top cop
column3: Steve McGarrett. Accepting meant moving to Oahu
column4: in the center of the planet‚Äôs loveliest island archipelago. It should have been a no-brainer. Cue that big wave and the theme song by the Ventures:Dum-duh-da-da-da-dum‚Ä¶‚ÄúI was conflicted
column6: reflecting on the decision from his house in Waikiki‚Äôs idyllic Diamond Head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd done two network shows before that
column7: neither of which had gone past a season.‚Äù He‚Äôd played vampire/private investigator Mick St. John on the short-lived 2007 supernatural romance Moonlight. A year later
column8: he was Dr. Andy Yablonski on the medical drama Three Rivers
column9: canceled after just eight episodes. Though anything seemed better than being penniless in Los Angeles
column10: to suffer through another failed show in the middle of the Pacific
column13: was a risk he wasn‚Äôt sure he wanted to take.‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know anything about Hawaii. I asked everyone
column14: ‚ÄòWhat do I do? Is this the right move?‚Äô‚Äù O‚ÄôLoughlin says. ‚ÄúEverybody was like
column15: 'Are you crazy? What‚Äôs wrong with you?‚Äô‚ÄùHe took the gig
column16: staying on Waikiki Beach. For fans of the show
column17: that‚Äôs where McGarrett and partner Danny ‚ÄúDanno‚Äù Williams were recently snookered into a joint spa weekend with their significant others.    ‚ÄúIt was beautiful
column18: but I didn‚Äôt get to see the real Hawaii
column19: ‚Äù O'Loughlin says. ‚ÄúI got a glimpse of something that wasn‚Äôt what Hawaii is. The weird
column21: crazy hotel part. I still didn‚Äôt know how I felt about it
column22: but the pilot felt really good.‚ÄùIt was
column24: a really good pilot. In the nail-biting prelude
column25: naval commander McGarrett‚Äôs convoy comes under rocket fire in the mountains of South Korea by baddies out to free his arms-dealer prisoner
column27: McGarrett listens on his satellite phone as his father
column29: is killed on Oahu by Anton‚Äôs brother
column30: Victor‚Äîthough not before the Honolulu Police Department veteran leaves his son a few cryptic last words.By the time that wave breaks and the opening credits roll
column31: you‚Äôre hooked: McGarrett has a vendetta and a mystery to solve
column32: and you‚Äôre coming along with him. Reboots are tough
column34: coupled with O'Loughlin‚Äôs chiseled portrayal of McGarrett
column35: made the 21st century Hawaii Five-0 an instant hit. Suddenly
column36: Oahu started feeling more certain.‚ÄúPeople say these islands either embrace you or push you away
column38: as a gift from the islands
column39: being blessed in and given a Hawaiian name. I found all sorts of things drawing me in deeper and deeper.‚Äù    With a full season to shoot
column40: he started to learn the local rhythms from friends
column41: like fellow cast member Daniel Dae Kim
column42: whose knowledge of Oahu stretches back to his days filming Lost. He took up surfing. A few years in
column43: he flew in some friends from back home in Australia to help him rebuild a midcentury modern home he‚Äôd found in Diamond Head that had ‚Äúspectacular bones.‚ÄùThen he met the Hawaiian surfer and model Malia Jones. The couple had a son
column46: and later married. The house filled with boys. O'Loughlin brought to the family his teenage son
column48: and Jones brought a son from a previous marriage
column49: Spike.‚ÄúI‚Äôm about to use the G word to embrace the scope
column50: ‚Äù O'Loughlin says. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs out there. I don‚Äôt know whether there‚Äôs a God or whether there‚Äôs lots of gods or whether there‚Äôs just universal energy
column51: but I know from what‚Äôs happened that there‚Äôs something bigger than me.‚ÄùAs O'Loughlin‚Äôs life was progressing on Oahu
column53: albeit down a much rockier family path. He avenged the death of his father. His mother
column55: believed to be dead for 20 years
column57: having faked her death to escape threats from her CIA past.He vanquished his true nemesis‚Äîthe nefarious crime boss Wo Fat‚Äîwho over the course of seasons framed him for the murder of Hawaii‚Äôs governor
column59: and revealed himself to be McGarrett‚Äôs virtual half-brother. He‚Äôs had two romantic relationships and has spent a lot of time shirtless and even more time kicking sundry bad guy ass.Hawaii Five-0 seasons are epic‚Äîeach a whopping 25 episodes. Multiply that by six and you wind up at Episode 150. Playing a character for that long does things to you. O'Loughlin is in territory where few actors ever get to tread. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs such a massive volume
column60: ‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThis has been a master class for me. I can definitely drop into McGarrett‚Äôs head space anytime. I have a bible of who he is in my soul
column61: in my mind.‚ÄùWith Wo Fat and his family issues somewhat in the rearview
column62: McGarrett seems to be finding a modicum of peace on the show. ‚ÄúThis season has been more of an easy-peasy McGarrett
column63: ‚Äù O‚ÄôLoughlin says. ‚ÄúHe still misses his dad
column64: and the thing with Doris still hasn‚Äôt totally left him. But it‚Äôs not all like
column65: 'Argh! I‚Äôve got to save the world!‚Äô‚ÄùStill
column66: O'Loughlin is happy to leave the character behind when shooting wraps. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a proper tough guy and a Navy SEAL. He‚Äôs always ready to go
column68: 'What are we doing? What do we got?‚Äô I‚Äôve had the great fortune of being exposed to a lot of Navy SEALs
column69: who‚Äôve helped me with the character. They‚Äôre terrific guys. But being like them requires a specific sort of energy
column70: and I have to manufacture that energy
column71: ‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúAt the end of the day it‚Äôs like
column72: 'Keep calm and have another cold one.‚Äô‚Äù    Paradise hasn‚Äôt been all surf and breathtaking sunsets. McGarrett may be a SEAL and a Teflon super-cop
column74: and injuries have taken their toll. In the first few seasons
column75: he elected to do most of his own stunts
column76: which he says was a mistake. He rattles off a litany of fractures and lacerations that could rival a snapshot collection of charts in any emergency room.‚ÄúI blew one of my knees
column81: ‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve knocked my front teeth out. I‚Äôve got fake front teeth. I tore my right shoulder to pieces‚Äîthree external tears
column82: a labrum tear and a detachment of the bicep tendon. My current favorite injury is two herniated discs in my lower lumbar
column83: which I‚Äôm receiving stem cell treatment for to avoid surgery.‚ÄùThat last injury spooked O'Loughlin. Always athletic
column84: he had to give up everything except swimming. The pain was so great
column85: he could barely rouse himself from bed
column86: and he worried about being able to throw a football with his grandkids.Signed on to Hawaii Five-0 through eight seasons
column87: he began talking about walking away while he felt he still could. But recently
column89: and those stem cell injections? They‚Äôve been ‚Äúmagic
column90: ‚Äù he says. Does this mean he might challenge Jack Lord‚Äôs record 12 seasons as McGarrett?‚ÄúThat would be a miracle
column91: ‚Äù O‚ÄôLoughlin says with a laugh. ‚ÄúBut I can see coming back and doing another season or two. I think this show is everything. It‚Äôs the core of it all.‚ÄùOne thing is certain: O'Loughlin has found his home.‚ÄúThe majority of my important memories are now Hawaiian memories
column92: ‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve just got to look around. You‚Äôve just got to watch the waves in the winter here. There‚Äôs something bigger than me in the world
column93: and I feel like that source or whatever that is had something to do with this whole journey for me
column94: because now it all makes sense.‚ÄùBy Ryan Devlin | Photography by Nino Mu√±oz | Styled by Lily Unkhoff.Originally published in Watch! Magazine

But the Global Seed Vault
column2: buried in a mountain deep inside the Arctic circle
column3: has been breached after global warming produced extraordinary temperatures over the winter
column4: sending meltwater gushing into the entrance tunnel. The vault is on the Norwegian island of Spitsbergen and contains almost a million packets of seeds
column5: each a variety of an important food crop. When it was opened in 2008
column6: the deep permafrost through which the vault was sunk was expected to provide ‚Äúfailsafe‚Äù protection against ‚Äúthe challenge of natural or man-made disasters‚Äù.  Well

column9: we sure do deserve to go extinct? " False link

Doctor finds anecdotal evidence that people are passing kidney stones after riding on Big Thunder Mountain Railroad at Disney World 2. Doctor makes 3-D model of kidney
column2: complete with stones and urine (his own)
column3: takes it on Big Thunder Mountain Railroad 60 times 3.¬†‚ÄúThe stones passed 63.89 percent of the time while the kidneys were in the back of the car. When they were in the front
column4: the passage rate was only 16.67 percent. That‚Äôs based on only 60 rides on a single coaster
column5: and Wartinger guards his excitement in the journal article: ‚ÄòPreliminary study findings support the anecdotal evidence that a ride on a moderate-intensity roller coaster could benefit some patients with small kidney stones.‚Äô‚Äù 4.¬†‚ÄúSome rides are going to be more advantageous for some patients than other rides. So I wouldn‚Äôt say that the only ride that helps you pass stones is Big Thunder Mountain. That‚Äôs grossly inaccurate.‚Äù 5.¬†‚ÄúHis advice for now: If you know you have a stone that‚Äôs smaller than five millimeters
column6: riding a series of roller coasters could help you pass that stone before it gets to an obstructive size and either causes debilitating colic or requires a $10
column7: 000 procedure to try and break it up. And even once a stone is broken up using shock waves
column8: tiny fragments and ‚Äúdust‚Äù remain that need to be passed. The coaster could help with that
column9: too.‚Äù SCIENCE: IT WORKS  Update:¬† ‚ÄúIn all
column10: we used 174 kidney stones of varying shapes
column11: sizes and weights to see if each model worked on the same ride and on two other roller coasters
column12: ‚Äù Wartinger said. ‚ÄúBig Thunder Mountain was the only one that worked. We tried Space Mountain and Aerosmith‚Äôs Rock ‚Äòn‚Äô Roller Coaster and both failed.‚ÄùWartinger went on to explain that these other rides are too fast and too violent with a G-force that pins the stone into the kidney and doesn‚Äôt allow it to pass.‚ÄúThe ideal coaster is rough and quick with some twists and turns
column13: but no upside down or inverted movements
column14: ‚Äù he said. MSU Today  I just love this because it‚Äôs HILARIOUS and yet also a perfect archetypal example of The Scientific Method: 1. Hypothesis 2. Experiment 3. Results 4. Discussion¬† 5. Conclusions 6. GOTO 1 (the scientific method is iterative

column1: alohaspaceman 160475175141 "2017-05-09 10:57:18 GMT" https://alohaspaceman.tumblr.com/post/160475175141/a-walk-on-water-we-are-surf-therapy-awalkonwater1 "  The Hollywood 360 sat down with Scott Caan (Danno
column2: ‚ÄúHawaii Five-O‚Äù) and asked him about his reaction to this fabulous organization.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been surfing my whole life and I have gotten so many benefits out of the ocean. ¬†When Pat came up with this idea
column3: he didn‚Äôt have to pitch me at all. ¬†I told him I was in. I‚Äôve seen what it has done for kids
column4: I‚Äôve seen the changes they go through
